attributes.alt: Book cover for From Our Hands: A Story from East Coast Migrant Head Start Project, featuring farmworker photography by Ted Hoffman. The cover shows four pictures of people working in fields of fruits and vegetables.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review alphabet letters
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat?
Recognize different kinds of texts/genres; Use information to describe.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Help children recognize words that have the same beginning sound, focusing on
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
What food is in the book? What does it look like?
What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat? Pretend you are eating your favorites!
Can you name three fruits? Can you name three vegetables?
Can you write about your favorite fruit? What words describe it?
What fruits and vegetables can you draw? What colors will you use?
What word makes the sound at the beginning of the word
What can you make to help you carry your fruits and vegetables?

attributes.alt: Book cover for From Our Hands: A Story from East Coast Migrant Head Start Project, featuring farmworker photography by Ted Hoffman. The cover shows four pictures of people working in fields of fruits and vegetables.

elements.text: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Phonological Awareness; Alphabet Knowledge; Writing
Use Circle Time to build background and teach vocabulary
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sounds.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Help children recognize and produce words with the same sound.
Guide children to think of new words that begin with the same sound as other words.
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
How is the food in your book like the food you eat?
Can you pretend you are gathering fruits and vegetables? Show me how you gather them.
Why is it important for our bodies to have healthy food?
Can you write about where oranges grow and who picks them.
Can you use these materials to make your favorite fruit?

Can you build a fruit market?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Let's Make Fruit Salad! The chart shows ingredients including 3 sliced bananas, 2 cups of sliced apples, 1 cup of sliced strawberries, and 2 cut-up mangoes. Next are directions for making fruit salad: 1. Wash the fruit. 2. Peel the bananas and ask an adult to help cut all the fruit. 3. Use measuring cups to measure the apples and strawberries and put them in the bowl. 4. Add the mangoes to the bowl. 5. Mix all of the fruit together. Finally, serve the fruit salad. Enjoy!

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas page for Let's Make Fruit Salad! The chart shows ingredients including 3 sliced bananas, 2 cups of sliced apples, 1 cup of sliced strawberries, and 2 cut-up mangoes. Next are directions for making fruit salad: 1. Wash the fruit. 2. Peel the bananas and ask an adult to help cut all the fruit. 3. Use measuring cups to measure the apples and strawberries and put them in the bowl. 4. Add the mangoes to the bowl. 5. Mix all of the fruit together. Finally, serve the fruit salad. Enjoy!

elements.text: Help children to pretend to make fruit salad using picture cards.
Invite them to use the picture cards to describe the process for making fruit salad.
What foods do we like?  Where do they come from?
How is the book like the one we read this week?
Pretend you are cooking. What are you making?
Can you tell me how we use cups to measure ingredients?
Can you write about how to make a fruit salad?
Can you use these materials to create a healthy fruit salad?
What word makes the sound at the beginning of the word
Can you make a fruit salad?
